InquirySpace

Learning Science by Doing Science

Students should learn science by doing science. They should select their own question, design and execute a study, draw conclusions based on their data, and communicate their findings.

InquirySpace activities guide students through the process of setting up an experiment, collecting data and analyzing that data. As your students progress through various hands-on and computer-based activities, they gain experience and confidence in scientific inquiry. In the end, students are able to design an independent project with their own research question, collect and analyze data, and present their results.


Get Started

Getting started is easy! As a teacher, you will register on the InquirySpace Portal, set up your class and assign activities to your students. InquirySpace offers guided, hands-on experiments that collect data using Vernier sensors and parallel simulation-based experiments where data is generated by a model with student-set parameters.

Students who are ready to branch out in their own direction will enjoy a large number of simulations that can be used for independently designed experiments.

Guides to Help You Get Started

  • Overview of InquirySpace
  • Register on the InquirySpace Portal
  • Screencast Lab Reports
  • Installing the Sensor Data Collector
  • CODAP Data Analysis Environment

  • Ramp Game

    Learn about independent and dependent variables in a ramp/cart system.

    Preview Teacher Guide

  • Spring & Mass

    Explore mass as an independent variable by collecting and graphing data from a motion sensor.

    Preview Teacher Guide

  • Spring & Amplitude

    Explore amplitude as an independent variable by collecting and graphing data from a motion sensor.

    Preview Teacher Guide

  • Spring & Mass Model

    Explore the effects of mass, starting position, spring constant and gravity on the period of a spring's motion.

    Preview Teacher Guide

  • Parachute Model

    Learn how a jumper's mass and the size of their parachute affect terminal velocity.

    Preview Teacher Guide

  • Parachute Experiment

    Use a motion sensor and coffee filters to learn how mass affects terminal velocity.

    Preview Teacher Guide

  • Independent Project

    Define and run your own experiment! Gather data using sensors or simulations.

    Preview Teacher Guide

  • Climate Change

    Explore variables that affect the Earth's climate.

    Preview Teacher Guide

  • Coming Spring 2015

    Experiment with one of our Molecular Workbench models and analyze data using CODAP.

How does Bayesian Knowledge Tracing model student development of knowledge about a simple physical system? Proceedings in Learning Analytics & Knowledge Conference 2015, Poughkeepsie, NY.

The Concord Consortium

Revolutionary digital learning for science, math and engineering

InquirySpace is a project of the Concord Consortium — a nonprofit educational research and development organization based in Concord, Massachusetts. Our pioneering work brings the promise of technology into reality for STEM education.
